text: FROM off a hill whose concave womb reworded A plaintful story from a sistering vale, My spirits to attend this

text: double voice accorded, And down I laid to list the sadtuned tale; Ere long espied a fickle maid full pale,

text: Tearing of papers, breaking rings a twain, Storming her world with sorrow's wind and rain. Upon her head a platted hive

author: SS

author: SS

text: Love to myself and to no love beside. 'But, woe is me! too early I attended A youthful suit it was
author: SS

text: to gain my grace  Of one by nature's outwards so commended, That maidens' eyes stuck over all his face: Love
author: SS

text: lack'd a dwelling, and made him her place; And when in his fair parts she did abide, She was new
author: SS

text: lodged and newly deified. 'His browny locks did hang in crooked curls; And every light occasion of the wind Upon
author: SS

text: his lips their silken parcels hurls. What's sweet to do, to do will aptly find: Each eye that saw him
author: SS

text: did enchant the mind, For on his visage was in little drawn What largeness thinks in Paradise was sawn. 'Small
author: SS

text: show of man was yet upon his chin; His phoenix down began but to appear Like unshorn velvet on that
author: SS

text: termless skin Whose bare out bragg'd the web it seem'd to wear: Yet show'd his visage by that cost more dear;
author: SS

text: And nice affections wavering stood in doubt If best were as it was, or best without. 'His qualities were beauteous
author: SS

text: as his form, For maiden tongued he was, and thereof free; Yet, if men moved him, was he such a storm
author: SS

text: As oft 'twixt May and April is to see, When winds breathe sweet, untidy though they be. His rudeness so
author: SS

text: with his authorized youth Did livery falseness in a pride of truth. 'Well could he ride, and often men would
author: SS

text: say 'That horse his mettle from his rider takes: Proud of subjection, noble by the sway, What rounds, what bounds,
author: SS

text: what course, what stop he makes!' And controversy hence a question takes, Whether the horse by him became his deed,
author: SS

text: Or he his manage by the well doing steed. 'But quickly on this side the verdict went: His real habitude gave
author: SS

text: life and grace To appertainings and to ornament, Accomplish'd in himself, not in his case: All aids, themselves made fairer
author: SS

text: by their place, Came for additions; yet their purposed trim Pieced not his grace, but were all graced by him.
author: SS

text: 'So on the tip of his subduing tongue All kinds of arguments and question deep, All replication prompt, and reason
author: SS

text: strong, For his advantage still did wake and sleep: To make the weeper laugh, the laugher weep, He had the
author: SS

text: dialect and different skill, Catching all passions in his craft of will: 'That he did in the general bosom reign
author: SS

text: Of young, of old; and sexes both enchanted, To dwell with him in thoughts, or to remain In personal duty,
author: SS

text: following where he haunted: Consents bewitch'd, ere he desire, have granted; And dialogued for him what he would say, Ask'd
author: SS

text: their own wills, and made their wills obey. 'Many there were that did his picture get, To serve their eyes,
author: SS

text: and in it put their mind; Like fools that in th' imagination set The goodly objects which abroad they find
author: SS

text: Of lands and mansions, theirs in thought assign'd; And labouring in moe pleasures to bestow them Than the true gouty
author: SS

text: landlord which doth owe them: 'So many have, that never touch'd his hand, Sweetly supposed them mistress of his heart.
author: SS

text: My woeful self, that did in freedom stand, And was my own fee simple, not in part, What with his art
author: SS

text: in youth, and youth in art, Threw my affections in his charmed power, Reserved the stalk and gave him all
author: SS

text: my flower. 'Yet did I not, as some my equals did, Demand of him, nor being desired yielded; Finding myself
author: SS

text: in honour so forbid, With safest distance I mine honour shielded: Experience for me many bulwarks builded Of proofs new
author: bleeding,

text: which remain'd the foil Of this false jewel, and his amorous spoil. 'But, ah, who ever shunn'd by precedent The
author: SS

text: way? Counsel may stop awhile what will not stay; For when we rage, advice is often seen By blunting us

text: to make our wits more keen. 'Nor gives it satisfaction to our blood, That we must curb it upon others'
author: SS

text: proof; To be forbod the sweets that seem so good, For fear of harms that preach in our behoof. O
author: SS

text: appetite, from judgment stand aloof! The one a palate hath that needs will taste, Though Reason weep, and cry, 'It
author: SS

text: is thy last.' 'For further I could say 'This man's untrue,' And knew the patterns of his foul beguiling; Heard
author: SS

text: where his plants in others' orchards grew, Saw how deceits were gilded in his smiling; Knew vows were ever brokers
author: SS

text: to defiling; Thought characters and words merely but art, And bastards of his foul adulterate heart. 'And long upon these
author: SS

text: terms I held my city, Till thus he gan besiege me: 'Gentle maid, Have of my suffering youth some feeling
author: SS

text: pity, And be not of my holy vows afraid: That's to ye sworn to none was ever said; For feasts
author: SS

text: of love I have been call'd unto, Till now did ne'er invite, nor never woo. ''All my offences that abroad
author: SS

text: you see Are errors of the blood, none of the mind; Love made them not: with acture they may be,
author: SS

text: Where neither party is nor true nor kind: They sought their shame that so their shame did find; And so
author: SS

text: much less of shame in me remains, By how much of me their reproach contains. ''Among the many that mine
author: SS

text: eyes have seen, Not one whose flame my heart so much as warm'd, Or my affection put to the smallest
author: SS

text: teen, Or any of my leisures ever charm'd: Harm have I done to them, but ne'er was harm'd; Kept hearts
author: SS

text: in liveries, but mine own was free, And reign'd, commanding in his monarchy. ''Look here, what tributes wounded fancies sent
author: SS

text: me, Of paled pearls and rubies red as blood; Figuring that they their passions likewise lent me Of grief and
author: SS

text: blushes, aptly understood In bloodless white and the encrimson'd mood; Effects of terror and dear modesty, Encamp'd in hearts, but
author: SS

text: fighting outwardly. ''And, lo, behold these talents of their hair, With twisted metal amorously impleach'd, I have received from many
author: SS

text: a several fair, Their kind acceptance weepingly beseech'd, With the annexions of fair gems enrich'd, And deep
author: brain'd sonnets that did

text: amplify Each stone's dear nature, worth, and quality. ''The diamond why, 'twas beautiful and hard, Whereto his invised properties did tend;
author: SS

text: The deep green emerald, in whose fresh regard Weak sights their sickly radiance do amend; The heaven
author: hued sapphire and the opal

text: blend With objects manifold: each several stone, With wit well blazon'd, smiled or made some moan. ''Lo, all these trophies
author: SS

text: of affections hot, Of pensived and subdued desires the tender, Nature hath charged me that I hoard them not, But
author: SS

text: yield them up where I myself must render, That is, to you, my origin and ender; For these, of force,
author: SS

text: must your oblations be, Since I their altar, you enpatron me. ''O, then, advance of yours that phraseless hand, Whose
author: SS

text: white weighs down the airy scale of praise; Take all these similes to your own command, Hallow'd with sighs that
author: SS

text: burning lungs did raise; What me your minister, for you obeys, Works under you; and to your audit comes Their
author: SS

text: distract parcels in combined sums. ''Lo, this device was sent me from a nun, Or sister sanctified, of holiest note;
author: SS

text: Which late her noble suit in court did shun, Whose rarest havings made the blossoms dote; For she was sought
author: SS

text: by spirits of richest coat, But kept cold distance, and did thence remove, To spend her living in eternal love.
author: SS

text: ''But, O my sweet, what labour is't to leave The thing we have not, mastering what not strives, Playing the
author: SS

text: place which did no form receive, Playing patient sports in unconstrained gyves? She that her fame so to herself contrives,
author: SS

text: The scars of battle 'scapeth by the flight, And makes her absence valiant, not her might. ''O, pardon me, in
author: SS

text: that my boast is true: The accident which brought me to her eye Upon the moment did her force subdue,
author: SS

text: And now she would the caged cloister fly: Religious love put out Religion's eye: Not to be tempted, would she

text: be immured, And now, to tempt, all liberty procured. ''How mighty then you are, O, hear me tell! The broken
author: SS

author: SS

text: among: I strong o'er them, and you o'er me being strong, Must for your victory us all congest, As compound
author: SS

text: love to physic your cold breast. ''My parts had power to charm a sacred nun, Who, disciplined, ay, dieted in
author: SS

text: grace, Believed her eyes when they to assail begun, All vows and consecrations giving place: O most potential love! vow,
author: SS

text: thine. ''When thou impressest, what are precepts worth Of stale example? When thou wilt inflame, How coldly those impediments stand
author: SS

text: forth Of wealth, of filial fear, law, kindred, fame! Love's arms are peace, 'gainst rule, 'gainst sense, 'gainst shame, And
author: SS

author: SS

text: do on mine depend, Feeling it break, with bleeding groans they pine; And supplicant their sighs to you extend, To
author: SS

author: SS

author: SS

text: then were levell'd on my face; Each cheek a river running from a fount With brinish current downward flow'd apace:
author: SS

text: O, how the channel to the stream gave grace! Who glazed with crystal gate the glowing roses That flame through
author: SS

text: water which their hue encloses. 'O father, what a hell of witchcraft lies In the small orb of one particular
author: SS

text: tear! But with the inundation of the eyes What rocky heart to water will not wear? What breast so cold
author: SS

text: that is not warmed here? O cleft effect! cold modesty, hot wrath, Both fire from hence and chill extincture hath.
author: SS

text: 'For, lo, his passion, but an art of craft, Even there resolved my reason into tears; There my white stole
author: SS

text: of chastity I daff'd, Shook off my sober guards and civil fears; Appear to him, as he to me appears,
author: SS

text: All melting; though our drops this difference bore, His poison'd me, and mine did him restore. 'In him a plenitude
author: SS

text: of subtle matter, Applied to cautels, all strange forms receives, Of burning blushes, or of weeping water, Or swooning paleness;
author: SS

text: and he takes and leaves, In either's aptness, as it best deceives, To blush at speeches rank to weep at
author: SS

text: woes, Or to turn white and swoon at tragic shows. 'That not a heart which in his level came Could
author: SS

text: 'scape the hail of his all hurting aim, Showing fair nature is both kind and tame; And, veil'd in them, did
author: SS

text: win whom he would maim: Against the thing he sought he would exclaim; When he most burn'd in heart
author: wish'd luxury,

text: He preach'd pure maid, and praised cold chastity. 'Thus merely with the garment of a Grace The naked and concealed
author: SS

text: fiend he cover'd; That th' unexperient gave the tempter place, Which like a cherubin above them hover'd. Who, young and
author: SS

text: simple, would not be so lover'd? Ay me! I fell; and yet do question make What I should do again
author: SS

text: for such a sake. 'O, that infected moisture of his eye, O, that false fire which in his cheek so
author: SS

text: glow'd, O, that forced thunder from his heart did fly, O, that sad breath his spongy lungs bestow'd, O, all
author: SS

text: that borrow'd motion seeming owed, Would yet again betray the fore betray'd, And new pervert a reconciled maid!'
